metadata.disclaimer: This database is for educational and clinical decision support purposes only. Always verify information with current prescribing references.

drugs.mechanism: Selectively blocks beta-1 adrenergic receptors in the heart, reducing heart rate, contractility, and blood pressure. Decreases myocardial oxygen demand.

adult.heartFailure: Start 12.5-25mg BID, titrate to max 200mg BID
adult.acuteMI: 5mg IV q2min x3, then 50mg PO q6h x48h, then 100mg BID

dosing.hepaticAdjustment: Start low, titrate carefully in severe impairment

drugs.mechanism: Cardioselective beta-1 blocker with minimal beta-2 activity. Reduces heart rate and contractility.

adult.acuteMI: 5mg IV, repeat in 10min, then 50mg PO q12h

dosing.renalAdjustment: CrCl 15-35: max 50mg daily; CrCl <15: max 25mg daily

drugs.mechanism: Non-selective beta blocker with alpha-1 blocking activity. Reduces heart rate, blood pressure, and peripheral vascular resistance.

adult.heartFailure: Start 3.125mg BID, double q2wk to max 25mg BID (<85kg) or 50mg BID (>85kg)

drugs.mechanism: Non-selective beta blocker affecting both beta-1 and beta-2 receptors. Also has membrane-stabilizing activity.
Highly selective beta-1 blocker with no intrinsic sympathomimetic activity.

adult.heartFailure: Start 1.25mg daily, titrate to max 10mg daily

drugs.class: Beta Blocker (Beta-1 Selective with Nitric Oxide)
drugs.mechanism: Highly selective beta-1 blocker that also stimulates nitric oxide release causing vasodilation.
Combined alpha-1 and non-selective beta blockade. Beta:alpha ratio approximately 7:1 (oral) or 3:1 (IV).

adult.hypertensiveEmergency: 20mg IV, then 40-80mg IV q10min (max 300mg) or 0.5-2mg/min infusion

drugs.mechanism: Non-selective beta blocker with long duration of action. No membrane-stabilizing activity.
Non-selective beta blocker with class III antiarrhythmic properties (potassium channel blockade). Prolongs action potential and refractory period.
indications: Atrial fibrillation/flutter maintenance of sinus rhythm

dosing.renalAdjustment: CrCl 30-60: q24h; CrCl 10-30: q36-48h; CrCl <10: individualize

drugs.mechanism: Ultra-short acting cardioselective beta-1 blocker. Half-life ~9 minutes. Metabolized by RBC esterases.
Inhibits angiotensin-converting enzyme, preventing conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II. Reduces aldosterone secretion and bradykinin breakdown.
Prodrug converted to enalaprilat. Inhibits ACE, reducing angiotensin II and aldosterone.

dosing.renalAdjustment: CrCl 10-50: start 2.5mg; CrCl <10: start 2.5mg on dialysis days
dosing.hepaticAdjustment: May need lower doses due to reduced conversion

drugs.mechanism: Prodrug hydrolyzed to ramiprilat. Long-acting ACE inhibitor with high tissue penetration.
Prodrug converted to benazeprilat. Inhibits ACE with high lipophilicity for tissue penetration.
First oral ACE inhibitor. Short-acting, contains sulfhydryl group. Direct ACE inhibition without prodrug conversion.
Prodrug converted to quinaprilat. High tissue ACE binding.
Prodrug converted to fosinoprilat. Unique phosphinic acid structure. Dual hepatic/renal elimination.
Selectively blocks angiotensin II type 1 (AT1) receptors, preventing vasoconstriction and aldosterone release. Has active metabolite (E-3174).

dosing.renalAdjustment: No adjustment for hypertension; 25mg start for hepatic impairment

drugs.mechanism: Selective AT1 receptor antagonist. No active metabolites.

dosing.renalAdjustment: No adjustment; caution in severe renal impairment

drugs.mechanism: Long-acting selective AT1 receptor antagonist. High bioavailability.
Prodrug rapidly converted to olmesartan. Tight AT1 receptor binding.
Longest half-life ARB. High lipophilicity and volume of distribution. Partial PPAR-gamma agonist activity.

dosing.renalAdjustment: No adjustment; start low in severe renal impairment
dosing.hepaticAdjustment: Contraindicated in severe; max 40mg in moderate

drugs.mechanism: Prodrug (candesartan cilexetil) converted to active candesartan. Tight, insurmountable AT1 receptor binding.

dosing.renalAdjustment: No adjustment; caution in severe renal impairment
dosing.hepaticAdjustment: Start low in moderate impairment; avoid in severe

drugs.mechanism: Prodrug (azilsartan medoxomil) with potent, sustained AT1 receptor blockade.

dosing.hepaticAdjustment: No adjustment in mild-moderate; avoid in severe

drugs.mechanism: Blocks L-type calcium channels in vascular smooth muscle, causing vasodilation. Minimal effect on cardiac conduction.
Potent peripheral vasodilator. Blocks L-type calcium channels primarily in vascular smooth muscle.
Blocks L-type calcium channels in heart and vasculature. Slows AV nodal conduction, reduces heart rate, and causes vasodilation.

drugInteractions.effect: Additive AV block and negative inotropy

drugs.mechanism: Blocks L-type calcium channels with predominant effect on heart. Strong negative inotropic and dromotropic effects.

drugInteractions.effect: Severe bradycardia, heart block, heart failure

drugs.mechanism: Highly vascular-selective dihydropyridine CCB. Minimal cardiac effects.
Potent arterial vasodilator. Available IV for acute hypertensive emergencies.
Inhibits sodium-chloride cotransporter in distal convoluted tubule. Increases excretion of sodium, chloride, and water.

dosing.renalAdjustment: Ineffective if CrCl <30; avoid in severe renal impairment
dosing.hepaticAdjustment: Use with caution in hepatic impairment

drugs.mechanism: Long-acting thiazide-like diuretic. Inhibits sodium reabsorption in distal tubule. More potent and longer-acting than HCTZ.
Thiazide-like diuretic with additional direct vasodilatory effects. Less metabolic effects than traditional thiazides.
Inhibits Na-K-2Cl cotransporter in thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle. Potent diuresis with significant electrolyte loss.

adult.acutePulmonaryEdema: 40-80mg IV; may double q2h if needed

dosing.renalAdjustment: Higher doses often needed; max single dose 200mg IV
dosing.hepaticAdjustment: Use with caution; can precipitate hepatic encephalopathy

drugs.mechanism: Potent loop diuretic. 40x more potent than furosemide. Inhibits Na-K-2Cl cotransporter.

adult.edema: PO: 0.5-2mg daily-BID (max 10mg/day); IV: 0.5-1mg; may repeat q2-3h

dosing.renalAdjustment: May need higher doses; continuous infusion preferred

drugs.mechanism: Loop diuretic with longer duration than furosemide. Better oral bioavailability.
Competitively blocks aldosterone at mineralocorticoid receptors in distal tubule. Causes potassium retention and sodium excretion.

dosing.renalAdjustment: Avoid if CrCl <30; contraindicated in acute renal failure

drugs.mechanism: Selective aldosterone receptor antagonist with minimal anti-androgen effects compared to spironolactone.
Blocks epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in collecting duct. Potassium-sparing without aldosterone antagonism.

dosing.hepaticAdjustment: Use with caution; avoid in severe

drugs.mechanism: Blocks ENaC in collecting duct. Promotes sodium excretion and potassium retention.
Competitively inhibits HMG-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis. Reduces LDL-C, triglycerides, and increases HDL-C.
Most potent statin. Hydrophilic with high hepatic selectivity. Not significantly metabolized by CYP450.
Prodrug converted to active form. Inhibits HMG-CoA reductase.

adult.note: 80mg only for patients on this dose >12 months without myopathy

drugs.mechanism: Hydrophilic statin. Not metabolized by CYP450. Lower myopathy risk.
First statin approved. Prodrug requiring hepatic activation. Take with evening meal.

adult.hyperlipidemia: IR: 20-80mg daily with evening meal; ER: 20-60mg at bedtime

drugs.mechanism: Synthetic statin metabolized by CYP2C9. Lower interaction potential.
Minimal CYP450 metabolism. May raise HDL more than other statins.
Inhibits intestinal cholesterol absorption at brush border by blocking NPC1L1 protein. Reduces LDL-C 15-20%.

dosing.hepaticAdjustment: Avoid combination with statin if moderate-severe

drugs.mechanism: Irreversibly inhibits COX-1, preventing thromboxane A2 synthesis. Effect lasts lifespan of platelet (~10 days).

drugInteractions.effect: Increased GI bleeding; ibuprofen may block aspirin effect

drugs.mechanism: Prodrug requiring CYP2C19 activation. Irreversibly blocks P2Y12 ADP receptor on platelets.

adult.stent: Usually 75mg daily x 6-12 months with aspirin
